body: SECAUCUS, N.J. -- Shawneequa Clark, who lives in Brooklyn, goes to Wal-Mart several times a month. She appreciates the variety, she enjoys the grocery selection, and she takes advantage of the savings. In short, she loves Wal-Mart. As long as it stays in New Jersey. Wal-Mart has begun another aggressive lobbying campaign to build a store in New
title: Welcome to Wal-Mart? Even Some of Its Fans Don't Want One in the City

body: MICHAEL SHANNON arrived at Frankies Spuntino in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, and avoided the busy back room, preferring to slip into a lone table up front. But at 6 foot 4 with a giant noggin topped off by a brow that could serve as a balcony, he's tough to miss. Add in the fact that he has been nominated for an Academy Award (''Revolutionary
title: THEATER; He Looks Like A Big, Scary Guy Because He Is One

body: KAZ CARTER-McGINTY was in the barber's chair (a red one with a steering wheel) for the first time in his life on a recent Saturday morning. He is 2. Kaz's hair, light brown and silky straight, fell almost to his shoulders in the back. The bangs in front had previously been cut by his mother, Miko McGinty, who now stood, camera in hand, giving
title: If You Love My Hair That Much, Mom, Take It

body: FLOWERS are blooming in the dead of winter on the fringes of Brooklyn. Inside Lindsey Gamble's bakery, an out-of-the-way, nearly hidden storefront at President and Columbia Streets near the waterfront, butter cream tiers and gum paste orchids climb high. A pile of blue fondant Tiffany boxes seems to tip precariously beside an edible high-heel shoe
title: Brooklyn's Allure? Fancy Cakes, Dahling

body: It's been more than eight years since I visited Ed Schmidt at home. A marvelously candid host, he told his dozen or so guests that he felt guilty that his theater writing wasn't providing enough money for his wife. Still, he argued, striving to be Thornton Wilder, futile as it may be, is a noble pursuit. Then he served lamb stew. When I visited him
title: THEATER REVIEW | 'MY LAST PLAY'; Oh, Come In. Glad to See You. Would You Like a Book?

body: FOR a place selling beer and pulled pork sliders, the Brooklyneer has provoked a lot of controversy. This new bar is dedicated to all things Brooklyn, particularly, the menu declares, the borough's ''newly-emerging food artisans.'' There are Brooklyn hot dogs and Brooklyn pickles and Brooklyn whiskey. You can order toast points spread with Boerum
title: Brooklyn: The Brand

body: TWO years ago Ed Schmidt, a New York playwright, got word that his father was near death in upstate New York. He bundled his family into the car and drove north, explaining to his young children on the way the sad fact that Grandpa might not recognize them when they got there. As it happened, they arrived minutes too late; Willie Schmidt, a former
title: Playwright Clears His Stage and Bookcases

body: FOR many, the very mention of step aerobics evokes images of exercisers in leg warmers and leotards, even though other classes have come to dominate group schedules at gyms today. In New York City, however, this seemingly faded fad from the 1990s is far from dead. Step, developed in the late 1980s, is a cardiovascular workout done on an adjustable
title: URBAN ATHLETE; Step Hits Its Stride Again

author: Christine Muhlke is food editor of The Times Magazine.
body: What confusing times these are. And I'm talking just about new cookbook offerings. Fall's usual glut of chef-y titles, primed for the giving, are notably absent. The food we're being offered is much simpler, much faster and removed from the realm of fantasy -- unless we're talking about ''Modernist Cuisine: The Art and Science of Cooking,'' the
title: Cooking

body: Housing Developments A giant gingerbread lighthouse illuminated with candles has gone on display at Oceana, 120 West 49th Street. Starting at 11 a.m. Wednesday at Le Parker Meridien, 119 West 56th Street, gingerbread houses created by seven bakeries, including Bakery Soutine, Billy's Bakery, Tribeca Treats and Norma's, will go on display. Visitors
title: Calendar

body: EARLIER this month, Tristan Chirico was trying to do some last-minute errands in New York before flying back to Jordan and his job teaching theater at a prep school there. The most pressing item on his list was a haircut. His plan was to head into Manhattan from the friend's apartment in Brooklyn where he was staying. But then, right there on Smith
title: The Barbershop Renaissance

body: IN the last couple of years, the tops of men's heads have provided one of those ironies that make fashion so endearingly silly. It started in the late 1990s, when fashionably antifashion guys began leaving their hair messy and matted, as if they had just rolled out of bed. A product even appeared called Bed Head to help naturally neat hair fall
title: Dig Out Those Pocket Combs

body: A BELL jangled as the young woman opened the door to G. Esposito & Sons Jersey Pork Store on Court Street near Carroll Park in this rapidly gentrifying part of Brooklyn. In her 20s, fashionably hipsterish, she seemed unsure as she ordered. ''I want the sandwich?'' she didn't mean to ask. Behind the counter, Santino Charriez, tall, shaved head,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD JOINT | CARROLL GARDENS; A Meat Store Grandma Would Love

body: John McFadden Jr. jokes that his fate was sealed when he was born the same year his father bought Staubitz Market, a butcher shop in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, that was established in 1917. Mr. McFadden, 43, got his start in the family business at age 10, sweeping up blood-soaked sawdust (the traditional butcher-shop floor covering). Now co-owner with
title: EXPERIENCE NECESSARY; A Butcher Who Lacks a Killer Instinct

body: Openings BERLYN The prime restaurant location for visitors to the Brooklyn Academy of Music has changed hands but remains in a Germanic mode like its predecessor, Thomas Beisl. Ursula and Jonas Hegewisch, the new owners, have found room to display their vintage pewter bric-a-brac, including a few gnomes. The chef, Steven Linares (left), offers
title: Off the Menu

body: MANHATTAN Gramercy Park Area . . . $390,000 145 East 15th Street, Gramercy Arms r 0 f 1 h 0 o 21 weeks 400-sq.-ft. studio co-op in a postwar building; 24-hr. doormen, dining area, h/w floors; maintenance $641, 56% tax deductible; listed at $439,000. Brokers: Corcoran Group; Weichert Realtors Mazzeo Agency. Hudson Heights ....... $542,500 880 West

author: Chip Brown is a contributing writer for the magazine. His most recent article was about the soprano Danielle de Niese.
body: The Prokhorov Effect ''Pretend you are putting a gun against my back,'' said the Russian billionaire. We were standing in a small training room on the third floor of his house outside Moscow. Suddenly he pivoted, and any ideas I had of sprinting off with his wallet went poof. His loaded foot was poised to crush my knee. You had to wonder, Did he
title: The Playboy And His Power Games

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Merchant's House Museum Friday and Saturday from 6 to 10 p.m., candlelight tours of the house; $25, $13 for members. This Sunday at 7 and 9 p.m., ''Spine Tingling & True: Ghost Stories of the Merchant's House Museum,'' told by Anthony Bellov and Dayle Vander Sande; $25, $15 for members. Reservations suggested for both
title: SPARE TIMES

body: ''Are you familiar with the Frisco?'' I asked a bartender at Rye House, near Union Square, who in turn asked me to repeat myself, then had me spell the two syllables I had twice uttered. Still he was baffled. He took out his iPhone and sought to Google his way to illumination. But the recipe he found didn't match my rough memory and sense of what a
title: THE TIPSY DIARIES; Smitten With a Cocktail Called Frisco

body: NEW YORKERS have been rediscovering a small neighborhood in Brooklyn called the Columbia Street Waterfront District -- and so have the real estate developers. The opening of Pier 6 in Brooklyn Bridge Park last spring, and the recent completion of a bicycle and pedestrian pathway along Columbia Street, part of the Brooklyn Waterfront Greenway that
title: POSTING; An Area Growing in a Family Way

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Merchant's House Museum For the next two Fridays and Saturdays and this Thursday, from 6 to 10 p.m., candlelight tours of the house; $25, $13 for members. This Sunday, 3 to 5 p.m., ''From Parlor to Grave: 1865 Funeral Re-enactment,'' a staging of the funeral of Seabury Tredwell, the owner of the house in the mid-1800s,
title: Spare Times

body: Ask David Wondrich how he became so fascinated with punch -- as in the liquid curse of many a holiday party, ladled out in portions too stinting to dull the pain of forced conversation and obligatory merriment -- and suddenly you're in England. In the middle of the 19th century. At Charles Dickens's house. ''He had this whole punch ritual,'' Mr.
title: THE TIPSY DIARIES; Dickens's Drink, A Pauper No More

body: DEL POSTO 85 10th Avenue (16th Street), (212) 497-8090; delposto.com. For roughly the last year, Del Posto's kitchen has been operating at the very highest level under the close guidance of Mark Ladner, who was the Puckish brain behind Lupa, a trattoria in the West Village that, like Del Posto, is owned in part by Mario Batali and Joseph
title: RECENTLY REVIEWED

author: Susan Silas is a visual artist who lives and works in Brooklyn.
body: TEN years ago I worked briefly as a production accountant on a television show called ''Welcome to New York,'' a sitcom starring Jim Gaffigan as a TV weatherman and Christine Baranski as his city-slicker boss. One episode was about a neighborhood dry cleaner who had magical powers as a matchmaker. The set decorator needed images of couples in love
title: MODERN LOVE; Sex on the Run? No, We Parked

body: MANNY HOWARD Amid a frenzied bull run in Céret, one of the unspoiled Catalan villages in Roussillon, France (''Sauvage Grace,'' Page 92), Manny Howard encountered a man wearing an orange life vest, blowing on a blue whistle, and holding a Hello Kitty boogie board. ''He was using it as a tray to carry glasses of pastis,'' Howard says. ''We managed
title: CONTRIBUTORS

body: 'CAT: THE OPERA-MUSICAL' A cat nestles just as neatly inside numerous English words -- categorical, catamaran, concatenation -- as it does on many a sofa and armchair across America. Few probably think about that, but George Plimpton did. His musings will gain new life on Sunday when Family Opera Initiative presents the premiere of ''Cat: The
title: Spare Times: For Children

title: Calendar

The streets are lined with friendly-looking Capes dating to the 1920s, each topped with a small brick chimney. American flags flutter from every other porch. On a
title: HABITATS | BELLEROSE, QUEENS; Home At First Sight

body: Back in the 1950s and '60s, New York City was studded with Chock Full o'Nutscoffee shops, homegrown institutions where the budget-minded could sidle up to the lunch counter for a freshly prepared meal. But the restaurants -- once nearly as ubiquitous as the Checker cabs that inspired their yellow-and-black decor -- were all but gone by the early
title: Classic Coffee Shop Returns. But Is That Salmon on the Menu?

author: E-mail: realprop@nytimes.com
body: $31.75/SQUARE FOOT $48,000 approximate annual rent 200 Columbia Street (between Degraw and Sackett Streets) Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn A bar has signed a five-year lease for 1,512 square feet of ground-floor space, with a basement and a 600-square-foot backyard in this four-story walk-up. body: 329 Smith Street (President Street), Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn; (718) 422-0444; Seersucker Brooklyn on Facebook.com. New Yorkers like their Southern restaurants in late-career Elvis mode: bloated, unhealthy, decadent, excessive and hip-deep in kitsch. There are no small plates in these dining rooms, only platters overburdened with countrified diet
title: DINING BRIEFS | RECENTLY OPENED; SEERSUCKER

body: The Dumpster divers started their bicycle run just after nightfall on a summer Friday, rolling through the steamy streets of Williamsburg and Greenpoint, stopping only to dig through trash bags and pull out produce. They wore plastic gloves for the messier bags and used a flashlight on the darker stretches of sidewalk. Then they loaded their finds
title: BROOKLYN JOURNAL; Sharing the Wealth at a Dumpster Divers' Feast

body: One morning in Brooklyn, Adam Grossetti lost his pants. The fliers he posted, seeking the public's assistance in the search for his trousers, included a brief description of the pants and of the circumstances in which he lost them. What may have been unclear, to those who failed to read the fliers carefully, was that Mr. Grossetti was not wearing
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; Have You Seen This Man's Pants? A Tale of Loss and Hope

body: IT'S an indelible image of summer: lemonade and cookies on a folding table on the sidewalk, a jar crammed with dollars, passers-by smiling politely. A 40-year-old man selling lemonade. Whether a sign of recession, regression or both, a handful of adults in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn have gotten into the lemonade-stand business this summer.
title: NOTICED; Sidewalk Entrepreneurs Grow Up

body: AT the recent Tales of the Cocktail, the liquor convention held every July in New Orleans, Erick Castro was working hard pouring drinks. Nothing new there. A San Francisco bartender, Mr. Castro has a decade's experience doing just that, most recently at the tippling den Rickhouse. But at Rickhouse he poured all sorts of liquors, while at Tales he
title: Bartending, a Dead End No Longer

body: DAN WOHL met Marisa Wallace on the job at the Barnes & Noble bookstore in Brooklyn Heights. She was hired to work with him in the children's department, and he was happy to show her the ropes. Two years ago, when they decided to find a place together, he was sharing an apartment with friends in Greenpoint and she was living with her family in
title: THE HUNT; An Affordable Apartment for One

body: LORETTA GENDVILLE is a mini-mogul. Her first Area Kids store opened in 2005 in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. She now has nine stores, including a new one (above) in Manhattan, at 55 West 14th Street, (212) 229-1700. She offers eco-friendly and locally made toys and clothing. Top sellers, she said, include Vulli's Sophie the Giraffe ($22) and Munipals
title: BROWSING; Think Green and Young

body: HERE'S Frankie Fidilio rolling down Avenue U in Brooklyn on the second-hottest day of the year in his blue 1986 GMC Suburban. The van has no air-conditioning, but that's the least of its problems. So much rust dust has accumulated in the back that this looks like the only vehicle in creation with a dirt floor. Still, that's better than the front,
title: The Real Junkmen of Kings County

body: RESIDENTS of East 94th Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, never expected to see a private driveway among the row of tidy brownstones on the north side of their block. But earlier this year, they discovered that the owners of No. 161, Andreas Gruson and Maria Negrete-Gruson, had built a nine-foot-wide driveway leading to their new one-car
title: Yikes! It's a Garage

body: RESIDENTS of East 94th Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, never expected to see a private driveway among the row of tidy brownstones on the north side of their block. body: 'THE MAGIC POT: THREE TALES FROM CHINA' This musical may remind you of a fortune cookie: sweet and uncomplicated on the surface, with pithy aphorisms buried inside. Written by Dane Stauffer, ''The Magic Pot: Three Tales From China'' draws on ancient fables. Tada! Youth Theater in Manhattan and SteppingStone Theater for Youth Development in St. Paul
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: If print is dead, the people who planned these events sure don't know it. On Friday the bookstore Freebird Books in Red Hook, Brooklyn, presents an evening of punk reminiscences, a fund-raiser for Books Through Bars, an organization that provides prisoners with books. Mike Edison, drummer for the Raunch Hands, hosts a talk with Eric Davidson,
title: Weekend Miser

body: Jim Neu, a playwright who was a mainstay of the experimental theater scene Off Off Broadway and whose work reflected on the quirks and excesses of American culture in wry wordplay, died Monday at his home in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn. He was 66. The cause was lung cancer, his wife, Carol Mullins, said. Over three decades, Mr. Neu
title: Jim Neu, 66, Creator Of Wry Plays, Is Dead

body: I grew up thinking of the bloody mary as a joyless drink. It was a corrective after a night of head-cramping excess: the pitiable hair of the shameful dog. Or it was a quasi-sanctioned, quiet way for the booze-dependent to begin a sort of intravenous drip of alcohol early in the day. Either way, the bloody mary struck me as medicinal. Today it
title: TIPSY DIARIES; Bloody Mary, The Liquid Salad

body: Seasonal Farm Stands Brooklyn Grange, a community farm in Queens, has scheduled seasonal farm stands, on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 3 to 7 p.m. in the lobby of the Standard Motor Products Building, and at the farm, 37-18 Northern Boulevard, Long Island City; and on Sundays from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. at Roberta's, 261 Moore Street (Bogart Street),
title: Calendar

author: Email: habitats@nytimes.com
body: WHEN Steve Chung began shopping for a new apartment in 2006, he was not looking for what you might expect from a single 30-something ensconced in the heart of the East Village. Mr. Chung, now 37, was living in a one-bedroom opposite the Beauty Bar, a boisterous hipster outpost. He had neither wife nor child -- nor even, at that point, a serious
title: HABITATS | CARROLL GARDENS, BROOKLYN; An Investment In Someday

body: Sean Dewhurst is a New York City pet-sitter with a fifth-grade education. He will enter sixth grade in the fall, at St. Ann's School in Brooklyn Heights. He started a dog-walking and cat-sitting service last year in the Carroll Gardens neighborhood of Brooklyn, where he lives with his parents, his three siblings and his cat, Jackie Robinson. Sean,
title: ENTRY LEVEL; At 11, Turning a Love of Animals Into a Job

body: IN a city that's ever on the go, it's a happy circumstance that there are so many decent sandwich shops. If inclined to, you can eat your meals three times a day between slices of bread, and in that manner dine lavishly. It's not just the same old sandwich suspects, either. Take breakfast, for instance, at the Prospect Lefferts Garden location of
title: $25 AND UNDER; Half a Loaf Is Better When Stuffed

body: To get to the city pool in Brooklyn's Gowanus neighborhood in the 1970s, a swimmer ran a gantlet. The pool sat amid factories and workshops, the streets around it crowded with trucks. Sex workers met clients near the gates, on Douglass Street. Still, clutching towels, local residents in need of a dip knew where to go, a block from the noxious
title: CITY ROOM; A Reprieve For an Oasis In Brooklyn With an Edge

body: Over the last decade, a growing stream of the young, the stylish and the family-oriented have been drawn to Brooklyn by its parks, waterfront, cultural life and relatively affordable real estate and acres of graceful brownstones. But when it comes time for those newcomers to have their babies, they are tied as if by an umbilical cord to Manhattan.
title: A Manhattan Birth Certificate, But an Address in Brooklyn

body: Early this week, after the city announced a new plan to combat rat infestations in subway stations, City Room asked readers to send in photographs of rats. They are still coming in, and we will publish them online early next week. But we also got something that surprised us: passionate e-mail messages defending, applauding, lauding and otherwise
title: For Some Subway Riders, an Abiding Appreciation of Rats

body: Openings RABBIT IN THE MOON Rocco Ancarola's gastropub with a stone front looks as if it belongs in some Yorkshire village, not Greenwich Village, except that the ivy is fake. The interior, with fireplaces, dark wood furniture and quirky artwork, suggests the Tudors. Brian Bieler, above, the chef (formerly at the Mott, Momofuku Noodle Bar and
title: Off the Menu

body: The new ''Food Lovers' Guide to Brooklyn'' by Sherri Eisenberg (Globe Pequot Press, $14.95) is reasonably up-to-date for a borough where new food places open their doors by the minute. Its 328 pages are packed, district by district, with detailed listings, maps and descriptions. Some of the neighborhood groupings segue from one into another, like
title: FOOD STUFF; A Borough's Treats, Now in a Book

body: New York City apartment buildings are often a menagerie of types, including old-timers who remember precisely who lived in each apartment 25 years ago, midlifers preoccupied with their families, and residents so new that they still find the clanging radiators and groaning midcentury elevators charming. But one outgrowth of the real estate
title: THE APPRAISAL; An Apartment Building Where Babies Reign

body: Today's project is crabs, blue-clawed and olive-backed, staring up fierce and rowdy from a basket, beautiful swimmers under arrest. It is summertime, after all, and somewhere a picnic table is sheathed in old newspaper and a bounty of jimmies and sooks piled high atop it. Old hands sit there expectant with hunger and glee. They have mallets and
title: FOOD; The Cheat: Shell Games

body: CENTENNIAL BEE-DAY PARTY In Kafka's ''Metamorphosis'' Gregor Samsa awakens to discover that he has become an enormous cockroach. While that may be among the most unwelcome transformations on record, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden will offer one on Saturday that's shorter, sweeter and sunnier: children changing themselves into bees. The process is part
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: RESERVATIONS? Not accepted. That is the blunt message for restless queues of hungry diners at a clutch of new restaurants in New York City, ranging from Má Pêche, David Chang's place in Midtown; to the Breslin, April Bloomfield's kitchen north of Madison Square Park; to Fatty 'Cue, Zak Pelaccio's restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. At these
title: Table for 2? Get in Line

body: Christina Nieves's life revolves around a handful of blocks in Brooklyn: Drop off her 4-year-old daughter and 2-year-old son at the Strong Place day care center. Make sure her 75-year-old grandmother, who uses a wheelchair, makes it to lunch at the Gowanus Senior Center. Then, on too many occasions to count, take her son, who is asthmatic and prone
title: Budget Cuts Hit a Brooklyn Area Over and Over

body: The Bklyn Yard, above, an outdoor arts and performance space along the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, is shutting down. For four years it held concerts by big indie names, including Dan Deacon and José González, and was a home for Sunday Best, a popular dance party. But in an announcement on Friday on the Yard's Web site (bklynyard.com), MeanRed, the
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Promoters Scramble as Bklyn Yard Loses Its Lease

title: Celebration at the Edge of Decay

body: THE template for setting up a Web site for a new development goes something like this: start with a flashy animated graphic, add a catchy soundtrack and paste a somewhat vague slogan across the page. Then wait for prospective buyers to roll in. The home page for a 44-unit development on the eastern edge Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, called Third and
title: As the Walls Went Up, So Did the Blog Posts

body: Sure, it's an expensive city, but it doesn't have to be. Every week we'll offer a select look at interesting ways to spend the weekend without spending a lot. Learn to parry with the instructors of the Manhattan Fencing Center. Some were members of the United States Olympic fencing team in Beijing, but they will teach foes of all ages and skill
title: WEEKEND MISER; Free Fencing Lessons, Yoga and Ballet

body: PAGES fly off calendars, as in old movies. Months blur into one another. Seasons collapse. Yes, Memorial Day is just around the corner. But in the life of a professional party planner, summer is just a place holder on the events horizon, a false lull between the benefit season that winds down this week and the one that cranks up again immediately
title: THE GIMLET EYE; For Planners, The Party Never Ends

body: THERE are really only two problems with Prime Meats, the very good and very beautiful Germanish restaurant in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. The first is that the restaurant accepts no reservations, which can wreak havoc on the evening schedules of visitors who come from beyond walking distance to eat there. You can see these people standing on Court
title: RESTAURANT REVIEW; Weisswurst Never Felt So Proud

body: ROSENDALE, N.Y. -- Until about a year ago, Fredrick Arnold was living the life of a Williamsburg hipster. An aspiring filmmaker with mutton-chop sideburns, he spent his working hours waiting tables at Dumont Burger, and his off hours on projects like an animated music video for one of his favorite bands, Casper & the Cookies. But after being laid
title: 90 Miles Upstate, A Brooklyn Feel

body: ERICA BUCKLEY has long since left the ranch house near Saratoga Springs, N.Y., where she grew up. But she has vivid memories of trotting across the yard and visiting her grandmother's house, which was just next door. title: HABITATS | LOWER EAST SIDE; Cats' Cradle and Baby's Crib

body: It's always nice to see a show that's kid- and gay-friendly -- why should audiences have to choose between bedtime stories and Lady Gaga, especially in Brooklyn, a borough that in recent years has had the dubious distinction of offering happy hours for moms? In a similar spirit of inclusivity and somewhat confused aims comes ''Le Cirque Féerique''
title: THEATER REVIEW | 'LE CIRQUE FéERIQUE'; Classic Children's Stories, With a Little Gender Bending Thrown In

body: IN early April, Kris Comstock, a representative for the Buffalo Trace distillery in Kentucky, conducted a seminar on bourbon at Char No. 4, a bar in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, that offers 150 kinds of American whiskey. Among the bourbons he poured were Buffalo Trace, Eagle Rare and Blanton's. But his students weren't interested in those. ''The first
title: White Dog: A Whiskey Having Its Day

body: WATERCRESS does not incite the kind of frenzy generated by ramps, those spindly wild onions that nobody bothered to pick until a few chefs began trumpeting their arrival as a major springtime event. But it is starting to show up in farmers' markets, too, and those who know it, love it. In a salad, as a garnish or in a sandwich, the first tender
title: Watercress, as Fresh as a Gurgling Spring

body: When Ari Laura Kreith moved to Jackson Heights, Queens, from California in 2005, it was not the 100 nationalities that are said to be represented in the neighborhood that captivated her. After all, California is a pretty diverse place, too. What made Jackson Heights unique, in Ms. Kreith's view, was that it had none of the ethnic dividers she had
title: Capturing the Vitality Of Jackson Heights And Putting It on Stage

body: Joseph W. Sarno, the cult director of ''Sin in the Suburbs,'' ''Moonlighting Wives'' and other films that helped establish the sexploitation genre and break down the taboos against erotic content in American cinema, died on April 26 in Manhattan. He was 89. The death was confirmed by Michael J. Bowen, who is writing his biography. Mr. Sarno bridged
title: Joseph Sarno, Sexploitation Film Director, Dies at 89

body: To ace the state standardized tests, which begin on Monday, Public School 172 in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, finds money for coaches in writing, reading and math. Teachers keep detailed notes on each child, writing down weaknesses and encouraging them to repeat tasks. There is after-school help and Saturday school. But at the start of this school year,
title: Low Income, Top Scores: A School Defies the Odds

body: A music review last Tuesday about a concert presented by Issue Project Room at the Old American Can Factory in Brooklyn misidentified the neighborhood in which the Factory is located. It is Gowanus, not Carroll Gardens.
title: Corrections

body: IN a city where the hot hangout changes by the minute, and people move to neighborhoods that are just starting to shed a commercial or industrial past, it is little surprise that New Yorkers sometimes wind up living in places that never before saw bed, sofa or stove. Some of the more intrepid renters and buyers over the years have set up house in
title: Born a Store

body: Gabe Pressman, 86, began working in 1954 for WNBC's radio station and then its television news. He has numerous Emmy Awards and is currently the senior correspondent for WNBC-TV, mostly as a blog writer on New York City news. He keeps working, he said, because the news is his lifeblood and because hanging around the apartment (at Central Park West
title: SUNDAY ROUTINE | GABE PRESSMAN; Watching the News, Not Reporting It

body: $3.15 MILLION 25 Carroll Street (between Van Brunt and Columbia Streets) Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn A developer plans to convert this vacant five-story 21,500-square-foot loft building, a former hosiery factory, into a residential condominium in the Columbia Street Waterfront district. Buyer: 25 Carroll L.L.C. Seller: Marathon Hosiery Company Inc.
title: TRANSACTIONS; Recent Sale

body: Morton Feldman's String Quartet No. 2 is hardly standard fare for a housewarming. Composed in 1983, the work runs more than six hours when played complete. But somehow it seemed ideally suited for the first public event mounted by Issue Project Room, a vital avant-garde performing arts presenter, in its future home at 110 Livingston Street in
title: MUSIC REVIEW; An All-Day Concert, but Only One Piece Was Performed

body: Looking Ahead FORNINO PARK SLOPE Michael Ayoub, above, is spreading the brand of his locavore pizzeria from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, back to the place where he had his first venture, Cucina, a Park Slope pioneer that opened in 1990 and which he left in 2001. ''It's a little surreal,'' he said. ''Some of the stuff I put in is still here. It's like
title: Off the Menu

body: To the Editor: Re ''Cleaning the Gowanus'' (editorial, March 4): The Environmental Protection Agency's decision to designate the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn as a Superfund site is bitterly disappointing to many residents and civic organizations in Gowanus that vastly preferred New York City's Superfund alternative plan over the federal approach. The
title: LETTER; The Gowanus Canal Cleanup: A Community View

author: Andrew Cotto lives in Carroll Gardens and teaches composition, over the racket of jackhammers, at the ASA Institute in Downtown Brooklyn. Join a reader discussion of his rant at nytimes.com/cityroom.
body: WE left Manhattan for Brooklyn in 1997. Even then, before it was the rage, it felt like a destination. We kept track of all the things the neighborhoods of Brooklyn had over the metropolis of Manhattan: actual diversity, affordable restaurants, more parking and less pretension. But the best thing, no doubt, every time, was the sky. Brooklyn had
title: COMPLAINT BOX BROOKLYN RISING; They're Stealing My Sky

body: NEW YORK used to be a second-string city when it came to coffee. No longer. Over the last two years, more than 40 new cafes and coffee bars have joined a small, dedicated group of establishments where coffee making is treated like an art, or at least a high form of craft. At places like Bluebird Coffee Shop in the East Village, the espresso is so
title: What's the Buzz?

body: Robert M. Scarano Jr., a Brooklyn architect who has long been criticized by community groups for flouting zoning laws, was barred by the Department of Buildings on Wednesday from filing construction plans -- threatening, at least temporarily, his ability to work as an architect in the city. The order, which applies both to pending applications that
title: Controversial Architect Is Barred by City

body: The Environmental Protection Agency designated the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn a Superfund site on Tuesday and announced plans to clean up more than a century's worth of noxious pollutants there. The decision ended a contentious debate and was a blow to the Bloomberg administration, which had proposed a cleanup without such a designation. The city
title: E.P.A. Readies Cleanup Plan For Gowanus

body: IN the nine years since he came to New York with $500 in his pocket, Martin-Christopher Harper estimates that he has moved at least 40 times. When he lists the neighborhoods he has lived in -- in chronological order -- he sounds like a bartender reciting a long list of microbrews: ''Brooklyn, Chelsea Hotel for a moment, Bronx, Carroll Gardens,
title: Boxed In

body: 'Savory' Festival From Feb. 24 through March 14, the Umami festival will feature programs that explore the relationship between food and art. It will be held in a number of locations around the city, mainly downtown, and takes its name from the Japanese word meaning savory, or the ''fifth taste.'' The festival is every two years; this year there
title: Calendar

body: Mr. Toll, 69, is the chairman and chief executive of Toll Brothers Inc., one of the country's largest builders of luxury homes. Toll Brothers was founded by Mr. Toll and his brother, Bruce, in 1967 and became a public company two decades later. The company develops residential communities in 21 states, including New York, New Jersey and
title: SQUARE FEET | THE 30-MINUTE INTERVIEW; Robert I. Toll

body: THERE was a television crew in Motorino in Williamsburg a couple of weeks ago, Michelle Park from NY1 shooting a segment with the restaurant's chef, the elegant young Mathieu Palombino. He smiled shyly in chef's whites. There have been others. Fame stalks the restaurant, which has locations in Brooklyn and the East Village. Vice magazine came to
title: RESTAURANT REVIEW; A Pizza Place Grows Up

body: FOR an entire year, Joe Foxton and his then-partner looked in vain for an East Village condominium. It needed to be a dog-friendly two-bedroom with outdoor space for well under $1 million. Mr. Foxton, 31, a native of Australia, graduated from the University of Technology in Sydney, and now works as the director of newsroom systems for NBC News in
title: THE HUNT; Plugged In and Happy

body: An entry on the ''On the Market'' page last Sunday, about a co-op for sale at 165 Carroll Street in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, misstated its price and maintenance fees. The price is $819,000, not $869,000, and maintenance is $899 a month, not $831.
title: Corrections

body: Andrew Marantz paid strangers to walk through Bryant Park holding hands and sharing secrets. Joshua Krafchin walked up and down a B train begging people -- to take his money. Amy Coenen placed 20 $5 bills, each inscribed with quotations on the theme of giving, in places around the city -- the straw container at a Starbucks, the floor of an
title: BIG CITY; With Just $100, It's Not How Much You Give, But How Imaginatively

body: THE view from the Brooklyn Heights Promenade, a five-block walkway that has overlooked New York Harbor from its perch at neighborhood's edge since 1950, is almost the same as it was 60 years ago. The Lower Manhattan skyline rises up, seeming close enough to touch, against a backdrop of clouds; tugboats push barges to and fro; cars and trucks race
title: LIVING IN | BROOKLYN HEIGHTS; The 360 From Here

body: LAST fall, a job transfer to Brooklyn from the Bronx spurred a series of changes for Briana Fedele. It was not just a good time to move; she also wanted to find a larger place with her boyfriend, Scott Cavagnaro. When she rented her tiny one-bedroom in Astoria, Queens, three years ago, she didn't have a boyfriend. Now she did, and as a professional
title: THE HUNT; On Monday Night, He Serves Pasta

body: New York City's mass transit network has become cleaner, faster and more reliable in the past decade. But its Web site remained stuck in the past. title: M.T.A. to Unveil a Makeover of Its Web Home

body: 'SNOW WHITE' How can a theatrical approach be both resolutely traditional and irreverently avant-garde? The border between those extremes is exactly where Company XIV dances -- sometimes on point, sometimes with folk-infused boot stomps -- in its fascinating new ''Snow White.'' As young purists might demand, this dance-theater adaptation includes a
title: Spare Times: For Children
